title: How to Make a Pumpkin Pie for Your American Girl Doll

methods.name: Making a Slice Using Craft Foam

steps.headline: Gather your craft supplies.
steps.description: Place them in an area where you will be crafting. Double check to make sure you have all your craft supplies before starting.

steps.headline: On the craft foam, trace four small triangles with a pencil.
steps.description: Use scissors to cut out the triangle shapes.

steps.headline: Glue the triangles together.
steps.description: Make sure they are stacked neatly together.

steps.headline: Trace another triangular shape on the light brown craft foam.
steps.description: Cut it out.

steps.headline: Glue this shape to the bottom of the stack you made earlier.
steps.description: This will form the crust of the foam pie.

steps.headline: Trace a small rectangle on the brown foam.
steps.description: Cut it out.

steps.headline: Glue the brown craft foam on the side of the foam pie.
steps.description: You might need to use a glue gun to prevent the side from falling.

steps.headline: Squirt a dollop of white puffy paint on top of the pie slice.
steps.description: Squirt some more paint on the sides of the crust.

steps.headline: Have the paint and glue dry until it hardens.
Finished.
steps.description: The foam pie slice is now ready for your dolls.

methods.name: Making a Whole Pie Using Clay

steps.headline: Gather your craft supplies.
steps.description: Place them in an area where you will be crafting.

steps.headline: Push down the orange clay in a foil cupcake wrapper (make sure it reaches to the wrapper).
steps.description: Smooth the clay using your fingers, or a spoon, to avoid cracks.

steps.headline: On the sides of the orange clay, pinch in some light brown clay.
Shape small pieces of white clay into balls.
steps.description: Glue these pieces to the clay pie.

steps.headline: Have the clay dry until it hardens.
steps.description: Your clay package directions should how tell how long the brand of clay takes to dry. Note that some clays take longer than others to dry. Some clays do not dry. They might need to be baked from your oven. Check the package directions to be sure.

steps.headline: Finished.
steps.description: The clay pie is now ready for play.

steps.headline: Trace ten to thirteen small triangles on orange construction paper.
steps.description: Cut them out using scissors.

steps.headline: Stack neatly.
steps.description: Then glue them together.

steps.headline: Trace a small triangle on light brown construction paper.
Glue this triangle piece on the bottom of the paper pie.
Trace a small rectangle on the brown paper.
steps.description: Cut it out.

steps.headline: Glue it on the side of the ‘pie'.
Crumble small pieces of paper and glue it on top of the 'pie'.
steps.description: Add some more pieces along the 'crust'.

steps.headline: Finished.
steps.description: The paper pie slice is now ready for using.

methods.name: Make a Whole Pie Using Paper

steps.headline: Trace ten to thirteen circles out of orange construction paper.
steps.description: Cut them out using scissors.

steps.headline: Stack and glue them together.
Cut a strip of light brown paper.
steps.description: Glue it around the pie. Bend the strip of paper a bit to make the crust appear more realistic.

steps.headline: Finished.
steps.description: The whole paper pie is ready for play.

text: Making a Slice Using Craft Foam Gather your craft supplies. Place them in an area where you will be crafting. Double check to make sure you have all your craft supplies before starting. On the craft foam, trace four small triangles with a pencil. Use scissors to cut out the triangle shapes. Glue the triangles together. Make sure they are stacked neatly together. Trace another triangular shape on the light brown craft foam. Cut it out. Glue this shape to the bottom of the stack you made earlier. This will form the crust of the foam pie. Trace a small rectangle on the brown foam. Cut it out. Glue the brown craft foam on the side of the foam pie. You might need to use a glue gun to prevent the side from falling. Squirt a dollop of white puffy paint on top of the pie slice. Squirt some more paint on the sides of the crust. Have the paint and glue dry until it hardens.  Finished. The foam pie slice is now ready for your dolls. Making a Whole Pie Using Clay Gather your craft supplies. Place them in an area where you will be crafting. Push down the orange clay in a foil cupcake wrapper (make sure it reaches to the wrapper). Smooth the clay using your fingers, or a spoon, to avoid cracks. On the sides of the orange clay, pinch in some light brown clay.  Shape small pieces of white clay into balls. Glue these pieces to the clay pie. Have the clay dry until it hardens. Your clay package directions should how tell how long the brand of clay takes to dry. Note that some clays take longer than others to dry. Some clays do not dry. They might need to be baked from your oven. Check the package directions to be sure. Finished. The clay pie is now ready for play. Making a Slice Using Paper Trace ten to thirteen small triangles on orange construction paper. Cut them out using scissors. Stack neatly. Then glue them together. Trace a small triangle on light brown construction paper.  Glue this triangle piece on the bottom of the paper pie.  Trace a small rectangle on the brown paper. Cut it out. Glue it on the side of the ‘pie'.  Crumble small pieces of paper and glue it on top of the 'pie'. Add some more pieces along the 'crust'. Finished. The paper pie slice is now ready for using. Make a Whole Pie Using Paper Trace ten to thirteen circles out of orange construction paper. Cut them out using scissors. Stack and glue them together.  Cut a strip of light brown paper. Glue it around the pie. Bend the strip of paper a bit to make the crust appear more realistic. Finished. The whole paper pie is ready for play.
